segments.text: Always coming out with optimistic.
Right.
What did you think about that?
Did you share that?
No, I think I just said that a minute ago.
I was very disappointed because, well, initially, you know, the first tour for the first three or four months, you're pumped full of vinegar.
But then you see my unit had been there since 1962.
And you start getting guys back in or you talk to guys who's,
been there, and they're saying, you know, we were doing the same damn thing in 62, for instance.
Our battalion maintenance officer on my first tour, a good friend of mine, Tom Cooper, had first, as a pilot, took his first hit at Doc Tobe in 63.
He came in with the company originally.
Of course, he was coming back to that company.
He liked that area, I guess.
I don't know.
And you think about it and you say, my God, you know, we're going back out and we're doing the same damn thing in the same area they did it before.
Well, I started repeating that cycle after about three months.
We're going into the same LZs.
A lot of times after the same units.
You get to thinking, well, this is bullshit.
Find out where these suckers live and get them.
And they lived across the border.
They lived in Laos and Cambodia.
And we would
have raids over there.
Those were special operations.
I don't know what the status is on that.
But we didn't go after them where they lived.
And had we gone after them where they lived, not necessarily with ground troops, but with special troops, and with effective bombing, much like Nixon did later on, I think we would have
put quite a strain on their logistics before they'd had a chance to build them up.
What about all the times Westmoreland said, you know, he could see the light at the end of the tunnel?
I thought it was bullshit.
I thought it was bullshit then, and I'm not talking 20-20 hindsight.
I have letters that I've written to my wife.
I've read you some of those letters.
In 1967, I thought it was bullshit.
That if we didn't change, we were...
not going to win.
And as a result, I became convinced we just need to hold on.
I thought, surely they'll at least hold on until we get this thing stabilized to the point that the South can take care of itself.
Next question.
I mean, Westmoreland was basing his, you know, his claims on the body counts and all these, you know, all the information that he was getting.
What about that information?
I have one personal experience with that.
There was a guy named Shriver at CAMDA.
It was a special operation.
We were working at the time, and he was leader of a reconnaissance team.
And he was across the border.
We put him in.
I went to pick him up.
And this was in late 67.
And Shriver indicated, now I wasn't sitting in the room, but I was told this, that there were Chinese passing.
And every time 10 had passed, he would key the mic.
He said he couldn't talk anymore, so he would just key the microphone.
He keyed that microphone 90 times.
Now, this area is Laos.
It's probably 50 miles south of the North Vietnamese border that we're talking about, maybe 75 miles.
I'm not sure.
They just have to give them maps.
That's been 20 years now.
Anyway, we took this guy down to Saigon.
He had to report to a brigadier general.
who was in charge.
And the Brigadier General told him he didn't see Chinese.
He didn't see anybody type of thing.
And old Shriver was not real political.
He was an old Special Forces sergeant.
He basically told him, General, I know Chinese when I see Chinese.
And I counted 900 of them, you can believe it or not.
And he was dismissed.
And the intelligence officer said after Tet
that said they had the same kind of thing.
You know, we told them this was happening.
We've told them this.

Now, either somebody in Saigon wasn't counting, or somebody in Saigon was counting and not telling the general, or the damn general was ignoring the numbers, or Washington was ignoring the numbers, or all of the above.
I don't know.
I know it would have been hard put to convince me at Pleiku

In 1967, when I watched the intensity go from minor problems in that area in January to major battles the size of the Saipan battles, I'm referring now to Dokto and places like that, major battles by the end of the year, that there was not a buildup in the infiltration.
Because had the bastards been in there that thick earlier, we would have seen them.
They had to be coming across the border.
Turn the fan off.
How old were you when you got to Vietnam?
I was 26, almost 27.
I was older, yes, and I was longer in service.
than the draftee.
I was about the same age as a lot of the regular line officers, but I was probably four years older than my contemporaries in the helicopter pilot area.
We had a lot of guys that were 18 and 19, right at 19, I guess.
We had a lot of them that were 20 and 21, so I was four or five years older than probably the average pilot in my area.
But then again, I had been in the infantry and had other aviation experience.
You think you were a little bit less susceptible than the younger guys there?
Yes, I was.
I was better trained, less susceptible.
To all the rhetoric of the generals?
I definitely do.
Because I had developed a good healthy cynicism to political things.
But I think also there were a lot of guys my age and older in the unit.
And so we tried to pass on some of the cynicism to the younger troops.
But it's amazing.
19-year-old kids have gone over the same area twice.
20-year-old kids have gone over the same area twice.
They're pretty good.
I'll give you an example.
Cheerio.
Young sergeant out of the 101st Airborne.
We were helping them down there.
I went cheerio.
Yeah, I went cheerio.
And he's got his knife out.
And this sergeant looked to be about 20 years old.
Fairly obvious draftee or young RA that had been there long enough to make sergeant.
He's cutting the hair off his arm, shaving little spots of hair.
And I says, what are you doing, sergeant?
We were waiting.
We were on five-minute alert to go make myself.
He says, cutting LZs for mosquitoes, sir.
And I said, why is that?
He said, malaria gets you four weeks in the hospital.
So pretty cynical approach to the thing, you know.
I mean, he's been a brave man.
He was a good leader, leading his squad and all of this.
But if I go out being ill, I'm sure that his answer was just an answer.
He was probably just checking his knife.
They didn't trust anybody except their own friends.
What effect did Tet have on morale?
Militarily, it was actually because we knew we'd kick their ass.
Now, I was back here, but I had friends that were coming back.
But as we watched the political events of it unfold, what had been a military victory, I mean, they practically wiped out entire units of the enemy.
We got over 800 of them.
One of my friends had come back from...
played coup.
They killed over 800 of them on the end of our runway out there.
We knew we had just decimated them.
And the newspapers were turning it around.
I mean, I was here watching it.

And I would have thought they had overrun the American embassy and was holding the ambassador hostage from the way the damn news was jumping up and down and the way Washington was reacting and jumping through the butt.
It turns out they had a sapper squad in there led by a young lieutenant.
that basically turned into a suicide outfit that never even got in the door of the damn embassy.
They blew a hole in the wall and got in the compound.
I mean, it's the best they were able to do.
But our own press...
They weren't supposed to be able to get that far, even on the embassy grounds.
Well, I would have challenged that.
I challenge the military knowledge of the individuals making those decisions and the reporters reporting them.
That's another reason to always be cynical of the press because you usually find that they're not that well educated, at least in the subjects that they try to write about.
And they don't care too much about calling with experts that disagree with preconceived opinions.
But three people were not supposed to be able to take 747s.
Four people were not supposed to be able to take 747s to the middle of the desert and blow them up.
Five and six people are not supposed to be able to get in an embassy and hold the entire embassy.
Half a dozen people are not supposed to be able to go in and blow something all to pieces.
Well, special troops and people who are dedicated terrorists can do this sort of thing.
And had the newspapers reported this as a group of special troops or commandos,
who had gotten into the walls, but we've got them contained, the American public wouldn't have been half as shocked.
But they may sound like, you know, they're coming out of the woodwork and coming through the floors and everything else.
Not understanding, I mean, look at how panic-stricken the U.S. is and a lot of other countries are today over terrorism.
They know that a few key, dedicated individuals can do a lot of things.
And when you bring out 50,000 of them,
and the few key dedicated individuals that are leading them, and you chop them to the knees.
The strongest military defeat, yet our press and the North Vietnamese public relations were able to turn that into a great victory for the North.
One of the things that's not generally publicized is one of the newspaper sources, and if your professor knows any newsmen, let him ask.
One of the sources was a local Vietnamese reporter who was in the know on everything.
And they would go to him for the true story.
And to the point that I think it was either Time or Newsweek had this Nguyen, whatever his name was, listed on their masthead as the assistant head of the Saigon Bureau.
Well, the day the country fell, the bastard was standing there in the uniform and markings of a colonel of intelligence, North Vietnamese regular army.
They didn't trust their own sources, so they go to this great source and ask him to check on them.
If he doesn't believe it, tell him to go back and get a 1973, 74, or early 75 issue of those two magazines and start looking down.
and find the Vietnamese assistant, and then tell him to ask Vietnamese who this man was.
That would have been like Goebbels editing the New York Times in World War II.
How do you think our victories would have looked then?
I can imagine.
All right, let's get back to you again.
You were there for two and a half tours?
Two tours plus two months.
Two tours and two months.
Why'd you finally, why'd you stay first of all?
Why'd you go?
Because I believed in what we were doing.
I believed in, I grew up in the, I grew into my teens in the 50s.
And I believed in my country.
I mean, World War II
I was five or six years old when it ended.
Patriotism and belief in your country was very strong as I was growing up, doing things for your country.
When our president stood up and said, ask not what the country can do for you, but what you can do for your country.
Those were real words to me.
I volunteered for a special unit, entered the service just shortly before that time.
Volunteered for a special unit then.
Because I felt that we had to stop the communists, stop them in Cuba.
The unit that I was with was supposed to give air support at the Bay of Pigs.
And that's the first time I got disillusioned when we were told that no air support, when the public was told no air support was promised.
I was in the unit that was going to give the air support.
And Jimmy Houck in Alexander, Louisiana, who's there today, was in the unit that was going to provide the air support.
That's when I first began to distrust politicians.
First began to question some of the decisions.
Like I said, you get cynical pretty early.
Go ahead with the next question.
Anyway, I believed in what we were doing.
And why did you decide to finally leave?
Orders.
So you were ordered out.

The American Army drew down in Vietnam in 1973, with the exception of a few, very few, unit advisors assigned to the Vietnamese Army and unit advisors or instructors assigned to the Vietnamese Air Force.
The country fell in 1975.
They're probably, if you notice, the evacuation was for the most part evacuation of civilian and diplomatic personnel, not massive units.
A lot of civilian personnel were over there maintaining aircraft.
Bell had a bunch of people over there on contracts to the South End.
A hell of a lot of civilians over there making money on contracts.
Damn few military.
doesn't alter the fact 1973 they had the drawdown my last time there was 1971 early 71 I was there for a Board of Inquiry at that time not anything related to something like Cali but the
American press, I think I read you the letter about how disgusted I was over the Cali affair.
I said that if this is true, that someone has made a terrible mistake in allowing such a man to become an officer in the United States Army, that this is Nazi Germany, not the American Army.
I was very proud of the fact that it was a helicopter pilot that stopped the fight, stopped the slaughter, rather, that he took his

guns off his door gunners and he told the American army lieutenant that if he didn't stop it he would kill him and the American army stopped the slaughter the American army lieutenant stopped the slaughter I'm very disappointed then that the army had the cover up I'm convinced that Cali didn't act on his own initiative without either benign neglect or quasi approval from above at least at the battalion if not the divisional level
And I believe this because I know the control that American units were under in combat.
For him to be able to go out and slaughter that village and no questions would be asked, he had to have known that no punishment would be forthcoming.
We had a guy kill enemy soldiers one time.
And he had been in combat a long time, but he decided he wanted that enemy soldier's skull for a candle holder.
So every time somebody would come out to try to get that soldier to bury him, he would strafe him.
And our commander threatened the court-martial.
He didn't knock that bullshit off.
For the most part, the commanders of the American Army over there
were pretty damned honorable men, a lot more so than I've found in civilian life.
They still believed in the ethics of your word as your bond.
And an officer don't lie to another officer.
An officer doesn't lie.
So when you left, it was basically part of the withdrawal, phased out.
Yeah.
Nixon's policy.
Right.
Vietnamization.
What did you think of that policy?
Was there peace and honor?
The policy as it was initially set up, we had spent several years training Vietnamese pilots.
I can personally vouch for that.
And some of them were pretty good.
They weren't as good in some cases as we were because I don't believe they, well, first off, they didn't have the mechanical aptitude that a lot of our people had
But they were pretty good pilots, and they were pretty dedicated young men.
So I can vouch for the Vietnamization coming along.
And we didn't give them a lot of offensive weapons, by the way.
And by that offensive, I mean something capable of going north.
They didn't have heavy bombers.
They didn't have heavy fighters.
They didn't have the legs on the little fire planes.
They had to go more than a couple hundred miles.
We set them up as a defensive anti-guerrilla army.
And when those tanks came down, they didn't have anti-tank weapons.
We hadn't given them anti-tank weapons.
They didn't have anything out there really capable of stopping tanks, mainline Soviet tanks, which is what came down in five-division strength.
If that happened, the contingency plan was the United States would come in and stop them, as we did in 72.
We went in there with tow missiles and the anti-armor capability and stopped the armor invasion at Khantoum and Dokto.
Yet when it happened the second time, our political will was destroyed.
A lot of it was destroyed by a press that, in my opinion, was duped or had other motives.
Now, he may say, hence sour grapes, but it's my opinion.
And the South Vietnamese Army did not have anti-tank weapons.
They didn't have anti-tank units.
And when those armored divisions rolled south, they rolled up just like anybody else rolls up.
Now, they could have stopped those tanks had they been suicidal.
They could have stopped those tanks had they been suicidal and properly led, yes, because the North Vietnamese were suicidal in a lot of cases.
They could have stopped those tanks with bodies leaping on them as the Hungarian stopped tanks.
They couldn't have stopped them indefinitely.
But when they wake up and see their senior French-trained officer corps beating feet, and they hear on the radios, and for the most part the young ones spoke pretty good English,
And they had shortwave radios all over the place.
And when they hear the United States saying, we're not coming in there, we're not going to do anything, who the hell expects them to stick around?
Would you stick around?
So Vietnamization worked as long as it stayed an anti-guerrilla, light infantry war.
When it became an armored war, they folded up the northern part of the country in a matter of days.
and then started south, and the rest of it fell of its own weight.
So they turned things over to them, but didn't... Well, we didn't give them the anti-armor capability, and we didn't give them the air support when they needed it.
Now, you asked me what I would consider a victory or something like that?
Yeah, that's my next question.
I thought you'd ask that.
What would have constituted victory in Vietnam?
A stabilized, democratic South Vietnam.
And I don't mean necessarily a U.S. puppet or anything of that nature.
A stabilized, democratic South Vietnam.
Democracy, multi-party democracy.
Socialism if they wanted it.
Capitalism to whatever extent they desired it.
Soviet client state is a total and absolute defeat.
I hear when I said the Soviet client states an absolute total defeat.
They now threaten the Philippines.
One of the finest submarine bases in the Pacific for the Soviet fleet that outflanks our Japanese lines of communication is now Soviet owned.
The aircraft sitting there threaten the Philippines and as you can see the Philippines are becoming unstable as a result of it.
The biggest

disgrace though is that we sat here for years when people were telling us what was going on the genocide that was occurring with the yellow rain and they say yellow rain is beefy that's a crock i have documents in my work yellow rain is not beefy it's a toxin uh

to allow three million Cambodians, a million Laotians, and thousands and thousands of South Vietnamese to be murdered and not say a word, not go in and militarily destroy the people responsible or punish the people responsible.
It's like chemical warfare because we kept our mouth shut over the Middle Eastern atrocities up until very recently.
We allowed them to continue, and now we've got the chemical warfare genie out of the bag, and it's going full guns around the world.
Well, the same thing happened with the genocide genie there.
They made a little bit of yelling after China was lost, and millions were being killed, but they never tried to do anything to stop it.
As a result, it was repeated.
in Southeast Asia.
That genie's out of the bottle.
There are the war crimes trials of World War II, the punishment of the guilty, the infliction of the fines on the country, the isolation.
Even to this day, Germany is still isolated in parts of the world because of what she did.
And the Soviet Union is beginning to
be understood and admit that, yes, there were several of those World War II millions that were attributed to death in World War II.
There were several million of those were Stalin purge victims of the 30s.
That genie's out of the bag, and we didn't do a damn thing.
And that's the biggest crime, as far as I'm concerned, that the same people who were yelling about the homicides that we were committing, quotes,
I know I've seen people die or take hits to keep them shooting in places that they were ordered not to shoot at.
They were that disciplined.
And to not see the press doing anything other than, well, the killing fields and stuff like that are starting to come out.
But the outrage that should have been occurring while it was going on wasn't there.
And they can't say they didn't know.
Thousands of people were coming out.
Photographic evidence was coming out.
These are the disgraces of Vietnam, not the fact that we lost.
The fact that we lost through such a political thing may have been a godsend because they've now created an attitude among the soldiers that I won't go to war again, but if I go, I'm going to win it.
They've got a real problem there.
I left the military and I still talk to my friends.
I believe that is the attitude.

may not say it publicly but i grew up with some of these guys that are colonels and generals now and i know how they think another problem is that the same people who were damning the americans are not only not yelling about paul pott they're trying to put his butt back in there and let him do it all over again if they don't
When the South Vietnamese, or correction, when the Vietnamese pull out of Cambodia this time, if they allow Pol Pot to take that thing over, they're going to have another killing field.
Another genocide.
And yet we're supporting him.
Our press is not talking about what a rotten SOB he is.
The man should be executed as a war criminal, along with
several of the leaders of the North.
The Chinese army that came down to teach Vietnam a lesson in 1979 didn't go reeling back because the South Vietnamese were such good fighters.
They went reeling back because their lead regiments were sprayed with nerve gas and mustard gas, and the Chinese army is not equipped for gas warfare any better than we are.
They went roaring back north after three weeks, not because the Vietnamese are such good fighters,
because they are the Soviet client state and they used gas warfare.
Now we've let that genie out of the bag and haven't yelled.

We've allowed genocide to occur greater than all the casualties that the French army and the American armies and the Australian armies and the Thai armies and all of the armies that fought in Vietnam.
They've allowed a greater genocide to occur without raising one word than all those armies
inflicted on all the soldiers they were fighting as well as the civilian population.
Where are these great peace lovers now?
Where's Jane Fonda?
She was up north making calls to us after she'd had her show in the South.
She's running around now that her political turkey of a Chicago 7 boyfriend is
thinking about running for other offices.
I understand they're getting divorced now, good.
But she was ready to apologize.
Well, with the Vietnam Helicopter Pilots Association, we all agreed.
When she apologizes to every goddamn name on that wall in Washington, then come talk to me.
But where is she in relationship to the genocide that has occurred?
And it's about to occur again as the North Vietnamese Army pulls out of Cambodia.
Where is the newspapers that should be raising hell?
Ask your professor to ask his students to ask their hometown papers that.
So that's the great defeat.
That is the great defeat.
It's the moral defeat of the things that this world had fought two wars to eliminate.
Gas warfare was outlawed after World War I.
It didn't come up except, well, the Russians and the Germans used it on each other once and claimed it was an accident.
We had a, quote, accident in southern Italy.
I mean, you know.
They didn't use it, even in their worst moments.
Countries were going down.
They did not unleash the gas warfare genie because they knew how horrible that stuff was.
And genocide, after the ovens of all the concentration camps were exposed, and after the prison camps of Asia were exposed, genocide was as chemical warfare.
Yet the political opportunist who came to power as a result of the 60s genuine movement in concern for peace, the political opportunist who came in power there,
didn't have the will to either militarily or even diplomatically raise cane, not only over the chemical genie.
They allowed it to begin in the 60s and didn't say a word about it until all of a sudden 5,000 people get 5,000.
Hell, they killed 14,000 coming across the shuttle waterway.
The only thing it was is they weren't 5,000 civilian Kurds.
They were 14,000.
Iranian soldiers.
Sprayed them just like fly spray, killed them as dead as a hammer.
I mean, they were still human beings.
And there wasn't a word said about that.
When they finally did decide to publicize it, it popped up for about a year, six months, and it's gone again.
Half the countries around the world now, third world countries, are building chemical factories because they, hey, we've got an answer to high-tech warfare.
That chemical genie was unleashed.
Nobody said anything.
Genocide was allowed to occur.
Nobody was punished.
That's the tragedy of the Vietnam defeat.
It's the tragedy of the lack of will of the political leadership of half the world as a result of the Vietnam defeat.
And the corruption of the American press, and I think to a great extent the corruption of the American school system.
Because there are certain, in my opinion, departments that are not necessarily
interested in teaching history correctly or teaching values correctly.
They're interested in fostering or furthering some private political agenda.
I'm not a rightist, I'm not a leftist, I think I'm a humanist.
That's bad.
Okay, the war, some people came out of it stronger, others it affected them in a negative way.
What effects the war had on you?
on your life since?
I made friendships there that are still as strong as family relationships are to this day.
It gave me a sense of values as to what is really important.
I've told my
children to choose their fights as carefully as they choose their friends, make sure they're worth it.
Because as you said, it did affect people in a negative way.
As you said earlier, I was more mature and probably a little better able to handle it than some 18 or 19 year old boy that was drafted out of school or off the streets, put into
basic training for three months, stuck in combat, and a week later he's seeing people that he had been talking to blown apart.
One guy said that there's nothing, and I believe this came out of, I'm not sure whether it came out of Vietnam or whether it was out of World War II, but I heard this statement or I read it.
There is nothing more dangerous than a 19-year-old kid
He just watched his buddy get his brains blown out.
So some of the things that these young soldiers did, they're understandable.
Some of them coming back mentally, having problems.
I came back to a wife, a new baby, and some sense of family security.
and back into the military community where what I did was appreciated.
Yet I came back on the aircraft with both times.
Very bad the second time.
Came back on the aircraft with young kids and landing in California or in Washington depending on where we came into.
In my case it was California.
You go down, take the bus from the base to the airport and in the airport
You have to wear your uniform because that's what you've got.
And you've got your ribbons on it.
And you have people calling you baby killer or making comments.
And I could see how that would affect a 19- or 20-year-old man.
Now, it made me very angry.
And the young hippie saw that if he pursued his line of questioning, he was probably going to get killed.
But you have to understand this kid has been in combat about a week before this occurs.
Thinks he's doing something right because he's been told he's been doing something right.
His country has said he's been doing something right.
His president and his generals have given him medals.
And he steps off an airplane.
And the first thing he sees is his contemporaries calling him fool, baby killer, murderer, spitting at him.
He wants to get out of that uniform and get away from that as quickly as possible.
And he goes into a community where there may not have been another veteran, unless he happened to have known him personally, because they weren't walking around advertising.
He had nobody to talk to.
When I came back, I had the five guys that I'd known for a long time.
And for four or five years after that, we went through our own withdrawal.
We drank.
We talked, we did our job, we flew, we did our thing.
But looking back on it, that was our way of dealing with the stresses, and it took two or three years to draw that.
There was no American Legion organization waiting there for him when he came back from Vietnam.
That was a home for World War II guys to sit around and swap glides and drink beer and play bingo.
And he goes to the VFWs looking at the same thing, or at the best, it was Korean guys that were 15 years older than him.
And
When you would go into those places, you'd hear, oh, well, yeah, you have to think, you should have been there in my war.
Boy, you won't see something.
I mean, he's trying to convince them this kid has just been shot all to hell or seen something like that.
I can understand how he got screwed up.
And in World War II, they had these camps for these guys who had really been in intense combat or POWs.
They tried to bring them down.
Army brought this guy back, dumped him on the goddamn streets with an early discharge because they were winding down, and put him on the streets back to his home.
The VA was a bureaucracy and still is a bureaucracy.
that was geared to help the World War II veteran.
And they talk a good deal about helping the modern vet.
But basically what they do is they leave the modern vet to get enough political power.
And that's why you have organizations.
I don't belong to anything with the Vietnam Helicopter Power Association.
I haven't even joined a church since that period, because I'm disgusted with organizations.
They don't seem to work.
But these veterans organizations, these quasi-things that were formed locally, in some cases nationally, that tend to get together and rap and bullshit.
I've seen guys sitting there that I know spent the war at Tonsenut.
And they're talking about how bad the war is.
And I've seen guys talk stories and those kind of things.
I've gone to these gun shows and talked to them.
And you find out where they were, and you start pinning them down.
And the closest thing I saw to combat is they might have heard an explosion.

they're claiming they're blaming all their problems on it i say there are some genuine casualties out of that war and they were not taken care of and that's a disgrace and everybody that was over there paid his dues and served and should be helped i don't care if he came back and in order to ingratiate himself back into this community he felt ostracized from it he became a doper or went 180 out was it to make friends again with people who he felt
wouldn't be friends with him if he didn't do that.
I don't know why they did it.
But there's no organizations there to help them, or at least to help them with any consistency.
What ties do you have with Vietnam right now still?
The Vietnam Helicopter Pilots Association, we won't allow politicians to address us.
We're a closed organization.
Anybody who flew helicopters in Vietnam can belong, even communists.
Our bylaws don't preclude the Red Army if one of them wants to join.
We've discussed that.
We've allowed the South Vietnamese helicopter pilots to join, Australian helicopter pilots to join us.
The only criteria is you had to have flown helicopters over there.
And our only action, other than getting together, checking on people, seeing who's where, helping each other if we can,
is to try to write history primarily of US Army aviation in the Vietnam War and correct it because we found that casualties were being hidden.
We've had a terrible time digging up the helicopter pilot casualties.
If a guy died on the ground as a result of his aircraft coming in and then he gets down and he gets shot on the ground, he's a ground casualty.
If his aircraft was sitting on the ground in an assault and got hit with a mortar shell, the fact that the rotor was turning, he had just landed and was attempting to take off.
The plane blew up.
It was not counted as an aviation casualty.
It was a ground casualty.
It was 10 years after the war was over before we knew that we were taking a higher casualty rate in the helicopter world than the Army or Marine infantry.
But as you can see from the book, we've got it documented.
We've dug out the government records.
And so it's to write the history of the unit, correct the records, and scholarships.
And that's it, other than just a network of good old boys.
Good old boys, huh?
